sub_topic: Probability of rolling a certain number on a dice
message_1: Suppose you roll a fair six-sided dice 30 times. What is the probability that you will roll a five exactly 5 times?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(X = k) = (n choose k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where n is the number of trials (in this case, 30 dice rolls), k is the number of successful outcomes (rolling a five exactly 5 times), p is the probability of success on a single trial (1/6 for rolling a five on a fair six-sided dice), and (n choose k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time.

So, plugging in the values, we get:

P(X = 5) = (30 choose 5) * (1/6)^5 * (5/6)^(30-5)

First, we calculate (30 choose 5):

(30 choose 5) = 30! / (5! * (30-5)!)
= 30! / (5! * 25!)
= 142506

Now, we can plug this into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 5) = 142506 * (1/6)^5 * (5/6)^25
â‰ˆ 0.2811

So, the probability of rolling a five exactly 5 times in 30 rolls of a fair six-sided dice is approximately 0.2811, or 28.11%.
